title: When you think of Cyber security, what's the first thing you think of?

_items.body:
Most people think of firewalls, malware detection, encryption, security implementation etc.

The 'technical' side of cybersecurity has become much more sophisticated over time, and as a result - much more difficult for hackers to crack.

So criminals have turned to an easier target - you.

Humans are currently the biggest point of failure in most cybersecurity systems.

Humans are fairly easy to manipulate. We all face similar pressures, and we share a lot of bad habits.

Criminals have learned to exploit people's psychology, emotional triggers and habits to gain access to systems that would otherwise be too difficult to crack.
They call this 'social engineering' - manipulating people, or exploiting weak practices we've overlooked to gain access to our sensitive systems and valuable information.

Most of us protect ourselves very well in some areas, and totally ignore or overlook other practices that put yourself at risk. Essentially - we're overconfident. Without a systematic approach to preventing social engineering attacks - we're all vulnerable.

This training will help you analyse your vulnerabilities to this kind of cyber-attack, and formulate a strong plan of action to prevent criminals from using you as a point of entry to do their damage.

displayTitle: When you think of Cyber security, what's the first thing you think of?

title: How do you evaluate risk currently?
body:
Some people evaluate their risk ‘objectively’ - but this isn’t true for most people.

Our brains often default to intuitive, "gut-feel" assessments of risk, which can be influenced by emotions, biases, and past experiences. While this approach might serve us well in some situations, it can leave us vulnerable, especially online, where threats can be subtle and sophisticated.

Taking a step back to assess risks more objectively can greatly improve our decision-making process. This might involve considering factors like the credibility of sources, the sensitivity of the information at hand, and the potential consequences of different actions. It's like putting on a pair of virtual "risk goggles" to see things more clearly.

So how do we do this systematically?

You create a personalised risk profile. We'll look at that next.
displayTitle: How do you evaluate risk currently?

title: The best plan is the one you follow
body: Most people don't have a systematic plan in place to protect their privacy online - but it's really not that difficult. Over the course of this training you'll develop your plan using the following steps.
instruction: Click on the titles to learn more.

_items.title: Analyse your assets
_items.body: What is valuable to one person (for example, sensitive photos) might not be important to someone else. What networks, systems, data, files and information do you need to protect? Think about your personal life, social life and work/school life.

_items.title: Understand your risks
_items.body: Learn a bit about cybercrime works, and why people might want your information or access to your systems. Learning to spot scams, traps and data collection schemes.Pause and evaluate your interactions online what risky habits or shortcuts do you already use? How do these habits put you at risk?

_items.title: Create a plan that's comprehensive and achievable
_items.body:
Once you work out what you want to protect, it's best to create a simple plan to adhere to - creating a complex plan is no good if you're not going to follow it every time.

One person's system might work perfectly for them, but not for you, take some time to customise it. There are a variety of strategies that can work, and all plans take a little bit of work, but it's important to keep your strategy simple and convenient enough that you'll follow it every time.

Over time, you'll learn more about yourself and the threats you face online, you're likely to evolve your plan. But to begin with, there are a few simple decisions you need to make, and some questions you need to ask yourself - and you'll create a solid foundation of digital privacy strategies to secure your information.

So how do you get started?

displayTitle: The best plan is the one you follow

Social: Reputational damage, social media account takeover, cyber-bullying, becoming a point of entry to attack friends, family or those in your social networks. damage to relationship

Professional/School

Financial: financial penalties,Theft of funds, fraudulent transactions, loss of revenue or business opportunities, increased insurance, hiring security consultants or PR

title: Risk, vulnerability and damage
body: Let's look at som terms that will help us better analyse our risks.This will help us assess our approach's strengths and weaknesses when developing our own personal privacy and security plans. This will help us assess our approach's strengths and weaknesses when developing our own personal privacy and security plans.
instruction: Click on the icons to learn more.

_items.title: Vulnerability
_items.body: A specific weakness or gap in your defences that hackers can exploit to gain access to your accounts, systems or data. An example could be a weak, reused or leaked password is a vulnerability.

_items.title: Damage
_items.body: The actual harm that could be done to you when a hacker accesses your data. Damage might be high or low. Gaining access to important data or financial systems would be very damaging, for example.

_items.title: Risk
_items.body: Risk is the potential for harm/damage, and how likely it is someone might take advantage of a vulnerability in your online security. For example: reusing passwords increases the risk that if one account is exposed all your accounts could be compromised.

title: What are some general risks to be aware of?
body:
Every risk can be plotted on a graph, but they depend on personal and organisational factors. Here are some examples of the risks people frequently take, how likely they are to occur, and the scale of the damage (also known as 'impact') they can have. Risks that are more likely, or can result in more damage/higher impact are the most critical to address.

As your review these general risks, ask yourself whether you do any of these activities, and what your own personal context means - some of these risks might be more damaging to you personally, given your level of access to various systems, how interconnected they are (say by ... a shared or leaked password) or the sensitivity or value of the data exposed by these risks.

title: How do we mitigate these risks?
body:
The biggest risks are the ones with the highest likelihood and the biggest impact. Your organisation likely has policies in place for many of these items, and many are fairly straightforward. Some of the most challenging risks are the hardest to deal with - because of a lack of information, personal attitudes and habits that make you less likely to comply with policies that are in place, or well-meant mistakes.

Next we'll look at three of the biggest issues - weak, reused or shared passwords, vulnerability to scams or 'phishing', and personal attitudes and habits.
displayTitle: How do we mitigate these risks?

title: Are your personal passwords professional?
body:
Let's talk about something we all do but really shouldn’t — reusing passwords. Most of us do it because - it's convenient, it hasn't caused us problems in the past, and we don't really have a better system. You only have to remember one or two (or statistically 2-4) passwords for everything. But here's the issue: it’s a massive security risk, and it can crack open your whole life, or your whole organisation.

Imagine this: a hacker gets their hands on one of your old passwords from some random site that got breached. Now, if you’ve used that same password for your work email or company accounts, they're in. Suddenly, they have legitimate access, and it’s like giving them the keys to the kingdom.

With access to a legitimate company email, they can move around unnoticed, sending emails that look completely legit to other employees. They might trick people into giving up more sensitive information or even authorize transactions. The hacker can dig through emails, documents, and other internal systems, stealing sensitive info, messing with company data, and potentially causing huge financial damage.

Password reuse isn't just a personal problem; it’s a gateway for hackers to infiltrate the entire company. Think about the client data, confidential projects, and internal communications that could be exposed. Not to mention, it can seriously damage the company’s reputation and lead to legal troubles.

So, in today’s workshop, we’re going to dive into strong password strategies. We'll cover how to create them, check if your current passwords are strong, and the best ways to save them safely as well as some reasonable strategies for keeping them up to date. We all need t make sure we're on top of our game when it comes to protecting our company—and ourselves online.

title: Reusing passwords
body: If someone in your organisation is using the same key for everything and you never change the locks, it means your organisation and all its members can be exposed by just one person letting a key fall into the wrong hands, even once. But how frequently do people actually reuse passwords?
instruction: Click on the titles to reveal how statistics about password reuse.

_items.title: Duplicate the same password for multiple accounts
_items.body: Most people who reuse the same password do it because they are forgetful and this strategy is fast and convenient. While that might be true, it increases the risk and damage that can be done for each account shared.

_items.title: Use one password for all accounts
_items.body: This is the riskiest behaviour you could use, even if that password is strong. Using one password for all accounts leaves you very vulnerable. Once a hackers gets the password to one account, they have it for all accounts.

_items.title: Use the same password for all work accounts
_items.body: This might seem safer and easier to remember, but once your work account password is compromised. Although this keeps your personal life and work life separate -  it means all of your work accounts are vulnerable.

_items.title: Reuse their passwords across their personal and professional life
_items.body: This strategy saves time, but ultimately is one of the riskiest behaviours you can do - the amount of damage that can be done to you and your company is astronomical.

title: What strategy should you use to create a password instead?
body: Strong passwords share certain elements. You can try to create your own, or you can use software to generate it for you. Here's some strategies for creating and strengthening passwords.

_items.title: Creating your own (less recommended)
_items.body:
If you’re going to create your own password, you should combine the following strategies:

Length: Longer passwords provide increased security against brute force attacks. Careful, many account types have a ‘maximum’ password length that might not allow an overly long password, and you must adjust your strategy to account for this limitation.

Complexity: Mixing uppercase, lowercase, numbers, and special characters enhances password strength, but overly complex passwords can be difficult to remember. Remember, the numbers for vowels strategy and adding a few numbers on the end is not a strong solution.

Avoid Dictionary Words: Avoiding common dictionary words reduces the likelihood of password guessing attacks.

Avoid Personal Information or easily guessed details: Avoiding personal information reduces the risk of targeted attacks, but some personal details may still be difficult to avoid entirely.

Use a Passphrase: A passphrase is simply a password, that’s longer, it could be a sentence, with spaces and punctuation in it. The benefit of a passphrase is that typically they’re easier to remember, but more difficult to crack due to their length. For every additional character in the length of a password or passphrase, the time it would take to break increases exponentially. Ultimately that means that having a long password or passphrase can make you far more secure than having a short one with some symbols or numbers in it.Passphrases offer a strong balance between security and usability, especially when composed of random words.

_items.title: Using a random password generator
_items.body: Using a random password generator is an effective strategy for creating strong and secure passwords. These tools generate complex, randomised passwords that are difficult for attackers to guess or crack using automated methods. By incorporating a combination of uppercase and lowercase letters, numbers, and special characters in a truly unique way, random password generators ensure a high level of security while minimising the risk of password-related vulnerabilities. Additionally, utilising a password generator eliminates the need for individuals to come up with their own passwords, reducing the likelihood of using weak or predictable combinations. Overall, leveraging a random password generator simplifies the process of password creation while significantly enhancing cybersecurity over other managers, but you are still left to update and store them somewhere - it is unlikely you can remember a number of truly random passwords - leading to the risk of reuse across accounts.

_items.title: Using a password manager
_items.body: Using a password manager to create and store passwords offers a convenient and secure solution for managing online accounts. These tools generate strong, unique passwords for each account, eliminating the need for individuals to remember multiple complex passwords. Paid password managers typically offer advanced features such as secure password sharing, encrypted storage, and synchronisation across multiple devices, providing enhanced security and convenience. While free password managers also offer basic password storage and generation functionalities, they may have limitations on features or storage capacity. Paid password managers often come with additional benefits such as priority customer support and regular software updates, making them a preferred choice for users seeking comprehensive password management solutions. Ultimately, whether opting for a paid or free password manager, users can significantly improve their online security by adopting these tools to create and manage their passwords more effectively than other solutions.

displayTitle: What strategy should you use to create a password instead?

title: Storing your passwords
body:
There are multiple methods of storing your passwords. There are different benefits and drawbacks to using different methods, but all have been used safely over time. The safest method is the one that meets the security requirements for your organisation and are convenient for you - so you don’t undermine your own security with less safe shortcuts (like sticky notes or reusing passwords).

Let’s look at some of the more popular and safer methods.

title: USB Encryption/Digital Password Book
body: Storing passwords on a USB drive with encryption or using a digital password book can provide a portable and secure solution for password management. With encryption, passwords are protected by a secure key, ensuring that even if the USB drive is lost or stolen, the data remains inaccessible to unauthorised individuals. Digital password books offer similar functionality, allowing users to store passwords securely on their devices, often with additional features such as password generation and autofill. However, it's crucial to keep the USB drive or device containing the digital password book in a safe and secure location to prevent unauthorised access. It’s important to also have a backup and regularly update it - think about how you’ll manage this before deciding on this technique.

_items.title: Tips for using this password storage technique
_items.body:
Use User-Friendly Encryption Tools: Use tools like VeraCrypt or BitLocker or Microsoft Office 10 (evaluate and use these tools at your discretion, they are suggestions only), which offer straightforward interfaces to encrypt your USB drive. Follow step-by-step guides or video tutorials available online.

Choose Devices with Built-in Encryption: Purchase USB drives with built-in encryption, like the Kingston DataTraveler Vault Privacy, which simplifies the encryption process.

Back Up Your Primary USB on a Secondary or Multiple Drives: Make copies of your files or digital password book and back it up on a secondary USB or external hard drive. Ensure that you encrypt the backup drive and back it up regularly, especially once you have added new passwords.

title: Physical Password Book
body: For those who prefer a tangible solution, a physical password book provides a straightforward way to store passwords offline. Users can manually write down their passwords in the book, keeping it securely stored in a locked drawer or safe. While physical password books offer simplicity and accessibility, they also pose a security risk if lost or stolen, as anyone who gains access to the book can view the stored passwords. For this reason, it's essential to keep the physical password book in a secure location and consider using additional security measures such as disguising passwords or encrypting sensitive information. This solution works well for people who are well organised and keep their documentation safe and secure and can be reasonably assured no one untrustworthy can access the book or be able to use the passwords, through simple manual encryption techniques.To remain useful, it must also be updated regularly, so think about how you’ll manage updating your password book when you’re away from it, how you’ll back it up, and keep it secure if you move this boo before using this technique.

_items.title: Tips for using this password storage technique
_items.body:
Buy a Ready-Made Password Journal: Purchase a dedicated password journal designed for security, which often includes features like tips for creating strong passwords and organised sections for different accounts.

Store in a Secure Yet Accessible Place: Keep the password book in a locked drawer at home. For added security, consider using a small personal safe.

title: Memory Palace Recall
body: Memory palace recall, also known as mnemonic techniques, involves creating vivid mental images or associations to aid in remembering complex information such as passwords. Users can visualise specific locations, such as rooms in their house or familiar landscapes, and mentally associate each location with different passwords or passphrase components. While memory palace recall leverages the power of human memory and can be effective for some individuals, it requires significant mental effort and may not be suitable for everyone. Additionally, there is a risk of forgetting or confusing passwords if the mnemonic associations are not maintained regularly.

_items.title: Tips for using this password storage technique
_items.body:
Start with Simple Associations: Begin by associating a password with familiar locations in your home. For example, imagine placing the password "1Sm1g?7-jj4" on your favorite chair in the living room.

Use a Consistent Method: Always use the same method for creating associations, such as visualizing a journey through your house where each room holds a different password.

Practice with Simple Apps: Use memory training apps like Memory Palace or Mind Palace that guide you through the process of creating and recalling memory palaces.

title: Password Managers
body: Password managers offer a secure and convenient solution for storing and managing passwords online. These software applications generate strong, unique passwords for each account, store them in an encrypted vault, and automatically fill in login credentials when needed. Password managers often come with additional features such as password auditing, secure sharing, and multi-factor authentication support. By centralising password management and prioritising security, password managers mitigate the risk of password-related vulnerabilities such as weak passwords, reuse, and theft. However, users should choose a reputable password manager with strong security measures and regularly update their master password for added protection.

_items.title: Tips for using this password storage technique
_items.body:
Use User-Friendly Password Managers: Start with simple, intuitive password managers like 1Password or BitWarden (evaluate and use these tools at your discretion, they are suggestions only), which offer easy setup and user-friendly interfaces.

Follow Setup Guides: Use the comprehensive setup guides provided by password managers, which often include video tutorials and step-by-step instructions.

Enable Browser Extensions: Install browser extensions provided by the password manager, which can automatically save and fill in passwords for you, making it convenient to use.

title: Enhance your strategies with the double blind
body:
The double-blind password strategy is a way to make your passwords extra secure by splitting them into two parts.You can use them with any of the above techniques.

NOTE: You will need to remember this add-on separately - it’s important to never write it down or tell anyone about this. If you ever share passwords - do not use this technique, OR use a separate double blind add-on. Be realistic about what you’re actually going to do - if you share a streaming site with your friends, we’re not going to tell anyone, but we will tell you - don’t be silly!

The technique is simple. Create a base password (preferably a truly random one). This password should be unique to this account and not shared anywhere. Feel free to store it using any method you choose (writing it in a book, storing it on a USB, using a password manager, etc.). Then, come up with your own memorable double-blind add-on. Whenever you enter a password, type or fill in your base password first. Then manually type in the double-blind add-on at the end of your base password. You only need to remember one double blind add-on, you can use this same code to all your passwords.

For example, if the password manager gives you "A1b2C3d4" and you create a double-blind add-on of "817@263", your full password will be "A1b2C3d4817@263". This way, even if someone gets access to your password manager, they won’t know your add-on, and if they know your add-on, they won’t have the random part.

Since it’s never written down or shared, it enhances the security of the passwords you do store, and if it’s leaked, it’s harder for hackers to use it. It takes a lot more work to crack these passwords.
displayTitle: Enhance your strategies with the double blind

title: Introduction to Phishing
body: Phishing and the more sophisticated Spoofing are types of cyber attack in which scammers use deceptive tactics to trick individuals into divulging sensitive information, such as login credentials, financial data, or personal information. These scams often involve impersonating the real person or organisation, such as banks, social media platforms, online stores, or government agencies, to gain the victim's trust.There are many different types of phishing scams, they are constantly evolving and new types of phishing emerge all the time.

title: Case study in Phishing
body:
Basic Stats:

  • According to a report - 83% of companies fell for a phishing attack in 2021.
  • 25% of all data breaches involve phishing.
instruction: Check out some phishing scams at these international organisations.

_items.title: FACC
_items.body: An employee from the FACC (an aerospace parts manufacturer in Austria) fell for a phishing scam. The organisation was asked to transfer 42 Million to an account held by the attacker. The message appeared to come from the company’s CEO.

_items.title: Crelan Bank
_items.body: A Belgian bank fell victim to a similar phishing attack. The attacker was able to spoof the email account of the Bank's CEO and emailed the organisation asking to transfer funds to an account.

_items.title: Sony
_items.body: The top executives (CEO) of Sony were phishing using a spoofed email address pretending to be from Apple. The email asked them to provide their login credentials and verification emails for Apple products, there was a link that took them to a fake website that captured their login credentials. The hackers were able to use this to breach Sony database and steal information.

title: Spotting a Phishing email
body: It's inevitable you'll receive many phishing emails. This one might be obvious, but can you spot all the telltale signs of a phishing email?
instruction: Click on the email to learn the warning signs.

_items.title: Suspicious email title
_items.body:
This email subject is very general and non-specific; which allows it to be sent to thousands of users without needing to be changed.

It also contains questionable grammar, while attempting a call to action by implying that something of yours (your "plan") has been modified without your knowledge.

It also ends in a code of random letters; and I don't really understand why (just makes it look less convincing).

_items.title: Malicious file attachment
_items.body: Shady emails will almost always contain an attachment. Under no circumstances should you EVER click it, as it almost certainly contains malicious scripts.

_items.title: Call to action
_items.body: Malicious emails will always attempt to coax actions out of you that will make you fall victim to their hacking or whatever. Note how in this example, no specific instructions are given; making the requested task nonsensical.

_items.title: Incorrect name
_items.body: Some malicious emails don't put in the effort to get your real name, and will instead refer to you by your email address. Professional companies don't (shouldn't) do this.

_items.title: Warnings from email client
_items.body: The email client itself has flagged this email as being suspicious.

title: How do cyber criminals target people's emotions?
body:
Although you may be familiar with signs of a phishing email, not all phishing attempts are so obvious. Even when people know what to look out for, they are still falling for phishing attacks. Experts in the field are still falling for phishing attacks -usually because they get caught up in the moment and ignore their privacy plan, or their plan was incomplete.

By learning how cybercriminals exploit your emotions, pressures and bad habits, you'll be able to protect against a greater variety of phishing techniques, even more sophisticated ones that aren't so obvious.

The best solution is to stay calm and analytical, and develop good habits when interacting with anyone online, or trying to access your information or identity. Stay vigilant even when receiving emails or requests from internal sources or trusted contacts - they may have been compromised, as well. These strategies are also used in phone,SMS and social media scams, so recognising and taking action to mitigate these tactics will help protect yourself from across different forms of communication.
instruction: Click on the icons to learn how cybercriminals target people's emotions.

_items.title: Fear
_items.body:
By creating a sense of danger, such as threatening account suspension, work or financial consequences, they prompt hasty actions like sharing passwords or revealing details.

Verify the legitimacy of these threats or consequences by contacting the entity directly through known, official channels, checking correct procedures before taking any action.

_items.title: Urgency
_items.body:
Implying a tight deadline, they rush decisions, leading to the quick clicking of malicious links.

Take a moment to think before reacting to urgent requests or review correct procedures. Legitimate organisations rarely impose sudden deadlines without prior warning.

_items.title: Trust
_items.body:
Masquerading as trusted contacts or organisations, they convince individuals to divulge sensitive information, click links or r

Independently verify the identity of anyone requesting sensitive information, even if they appear to be from a trusted source, or go through standard account access instead of clicking links.

_items.title: Greed
_items.body:
Promising lucrative rewards, they entice the sharing of financial or personal details. They may also be combined with urgency, urging you to act now or lose out on an opportunity or deal.

Be skeptical of offers that seem too good to be true. Research the offer and the entity providing it before sharing any information. Evaluate whether the value is worth the risk.

_items.title: Helpfulness
_items.body:
Appealing to the desire to assist or maintain good relationships, they solicit access to secure systems by pretending to need your help.

Confirm the identity of individuals asking for help and ensure that their requests are legitimate before providing assistance.

_items.title: Curiosity
_items.body:
Teasing intriguing content, they lure individuals into downloading malware, divulging information, or clicking malicious links.

Avoid clicking on unsolicited links or downloading unknown attachments. Verify the source and content through alternative means.

_items.title: Confusion
_items.body:
Creating complex or unclear scenarios, they overwhelm you, leading to mistakes such as entering credentials on fake sites or divulge information you shouldn't.

Seek clarification when faced with confusing scenarios. Take time to understand the situation fully and consult trusted sources if unsure.

title: Intro
body:
Note to self: stop calling these Extras. Call them something beginning with "R".

An 'Extra' is any additional functionality that is added inside of another Component.

I have made Extras very easy to add in the code:

<r.hyperlink href="https://google.com:">Click me!</r.hyperlink>do this

All Extras will follow the "r.XXX" naming convention. The "r" stands for "ReactComponent" (which is what "Extras" actually are).

Below are some examples of the Extras we have so far, used inside of the Text component.

title: Hyperlinks
body:
If you ever need to link to an external website, just do this. The little icon after it indicates that it's an external link.

If you want, I can also let you make hyperlinks which scroll you to a certain block (if you need a "go to" type of feature).

I've added a basic underline animation for now. I don't really want to spend too much time on animation effects when there's so much more to do.

An important thing to note about hyperlinks: The "unvisited" and "visited" state colours we use for these should also be the ones we use for ALL interactive content in this framework.

title: Graphics
body:
A "graphic" is any type of visual element your content could need; whether it be decorative, or informational. Meaning it could be:

  • An image.
  • A data table.
  • A blockquote.

While all of the above can be made using vanilla HTML elements, the following helper will allow for greater control down the line.
